did.head: Overview of the Collection

origination.label: Creator:
origination.corpname: Connecticut. Office of the Attorney General

did.unittitle: Office of the Attorney General records

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Before 1897, Connecticut did not have an Attorney General. In April 1897, the House introduced H.B. 344 to create the office of Attorney General to supervise all legal matters in which the State is an interested party. The Governor would appoint the official with the approval by the Senate. After the Judiciary committee twice rejected the bill, the House amended it to make the office elective. Charles Phelps, a Republican from Vernon served as the first Attorney General from 1899-1903.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The records were arranged into 4 subgroups and 8 series which document the . The series include .

Series 2. Case Files, , consists of correspondence; notes; invoices; newspaper clippings; exhibits; reports; motions; petitions; appearance notices; trial lists; extensions; briefs; demurrers; petition, bill of review, and application; complaints, application, order to show cause and writ; order and writ; application to be made a party; short calendar post cards; memorandum of decision; rulings; findings; motions to remand; bills of cost; and appeals. Merritt Parkway Files consist of signed vouchers, warranty deeds, title reports, abstract of title, mortgage documents, and blueprints of deed plans.

p.emph: Subgroup 5. Francis A. Pallotti vs. William J. Cox, 1942,

scopecontent.p: Series 8. Opinions, 1899-1971, consists of opinions and related correspondence.

p.emph: Series 12. Highway Department Reports of Accidents, 1917-1922,

scopecontent.p: Series 13. Workmen's Compensation Case Files, circa 1936-1962, may include agreements; compensation agreements; correspondence; approvals or denials of claims; injury reports; report of accident or occupational disease to an employee; physicians and surgeons report of illness or injury to state employee; surgeon's report to commissioner in cases of permanent injury; report of changes in personnel; motor vehicle accident reports; Attorney General collection reports; legal documents; notices of hearings; medical certificates; cards; bills; receipts; lists; and notes.

controlaccess.head: Organizations:
controlaccess.corpname: Connecticut. Office of the Attorney General

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Series 13. Workmen's Compensation Case Files, circa 1936-1962, are restricted due to Conn. Gen. Stat. sec. 1-210(b)(2) of the Freedom of Information Act which exempts from disclosure personnel or medical files and similar files the disclosure of which would constitute an invasion of personal privacy and Conn. Gen. Stat. sec. 1-210(b)(10) of the Freedom of Information Act which exempts from disclosure any records created as a result of a doctor-patient or a therapist-patient relationship.
These records are stored at an off-site facility and therefore may not be available on a same-day basis.
